keyTakeAways: A fuel tanker overturned and exploded in Niger State, Nigeria, killing at least 35 people.
The tanker was transporting petrol from Lagos to northern Nigeria when it crashed.
Petrol spilled after the crash and ignited, causing a large-scale explosion.
Several injured individuals were taken to the Federal Medical Centre Bida, many suffering severe burns.
The Niger State Governor, Mohammed Umaru Bago, expressed deep condolences and noted that some people tried to approach the tanker to retrieve its contents, increasing risk of injury or death.
The tanker drivers’ association chairman, Farouk Mohammed Kawo, described the incident as 'devastating and avoidable' due to the deplorable state of the roads.
A recurring problem in Nigeria is the transport of fossil fuels by road due to a lack of pipeline infrastructure.
Poorly maintained roads with potholes contribute to frequent accidents, resulting in dozens of deaths annually.
This incident reflects a broader pattern of road safety failures in Nigeria, especially in fuel transport.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fuel tanker transporting petrol from Lagos to Niger State exploded after overturning in the Essa area of Katcha local government, killing at least 35 people and injuring many more with severe burns. The Federal Road Safety Corps confirmed the incident, and local authorities expressed deep sorrow. The tanker drivers’ association attributed the tragedy to the deplorable state of the roads, noting 30 crashes on the same route in October alone. This incident underscores a broader crisis in Nigeria’s road safety, driven by inadequate infrastructure, the reliance on road transport for fuel due to the lack of pipelines, and poor road maintenance leading to frequent and deadly accidents.
title: Nigerian fuel tanker explosion kills 35, road safety agency says
